body:
I'm facing a similar issue. Try changing your tooltip line to `tooltip=["date_str", alt.Tooltip("date_datetime:T", format="%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S"), "value:Q"]` to see the time. 

Say your machine is in UTC-5, you'll probably find that where `date_str` is "2015-06-04", `date_datetime` was probably "2015-06-03T19:00:00". In my case, since my machine is on UTC+8, I'm seeing it as "2015-06-04T08:00:00".

It seems like Streamlit is converting the datetimes to the timezone on the local machine. If no tz info is specified for the datetime given, it assumes UTC. From what I've tried, this only seems to be happening to Altair charts in Streamlit. It does not happen to Altair on its own, and it does not happen to `st.line_chart`.

Thanks for reporting this issue! As suggested by @arcanaxion, the problem is indeed related to how altair processes date timezones. One fix from our side might be to always set the scale to `utc` for `datetime` objects ([as we do with `date` objects already](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/develop/lib/streamlit/elements/arrow_altair.py#L318)). But I'm not sure yet if there are any other negative sideffects if we do this.
This seems very related to https://github.com/altair-viz/altair/issues/2540 The solution would be to put the dates into the ISO-8601 format.

I'm bumping this up to a P2 since it also impacts the axis labels (as seen in the screenshot above) and we heard about it from a few places recently. I don't think the provided workaround would fix the axis labels, just the tooltip.

I don't have edit access on the issue, but would be nice if someone could update the title and summary to reflect that it's not just the tooltip impacted.

rename.from: altair_chart tooltip not displaying correct date
rename.to: Tooltip and axis labels are not displaying correct date for `st.altair_chart`

body:
Confirming that I experience this issue in the U.S. when using Streamlit, and not in Europe when using Streamlit.

It works everywhere in Jupyter notebook (without the `st.altair_chart` of course).

I suggest for the title to be "Tooltip and axis labels are not displaying correct for `st.altair_chart` *when the end-user is in UTC -X timezones*". üòÑ

issue.title: Wrong time label on st.scatter_plot

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues.
- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue.

### Summary

I use the function to demo a time series data while I found that the x-axis plot is correct but when I get the 'time' label for every individual point it's not. For the labels on the point they automatically shift 8-hours so the date changed to next date at everyday 4pm. After my investigation, the x-axis can correcly interpret the value in dataframe, while I manully correct the time-zone, but label still remain the same with auto-shift. Can anyone tell me how to off the autoshift things or I have to do some timestamps manipulation, this cause a huge problem on the data presentation with time series. Thanks.

### Reproducible Code Example

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Expected Behavior

Aligned timestamp on x-axis and label with st.scatter_plot()

### Current Behavior

autoshift on 'time' label

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this used to work in a previous version.

### Debug info

- Streamlit version:
- Python version:
- Operating System:
- Browser:


### Additional Information

_No response_

body: Still experiencing this as of Feb 2024, not a nice bug. I'm changing all tooltips to use a stringified version of the date meanwhile. :/

issue.title: Offset dates in vega if no timezone information is attached.

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
## Describe your changes

When Streamlit apps work with dates/datetime, Vega can show the incorrect date on the graphs. This is because datetimes are serialized as milliseconds since epoch and are therefore assumed in UTC format. Vega's engine takes in this timestamp and produces a Date that is set to the local timezone, which can create some incorrect values. There's also no way to determined from the serialized shape what timezone it is in, so we need to offset the time for vega.

NOTE: We do this a lot in formatting for tables, but this is specific to Vega's engine, so we isolate the change there.

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable)
Closes #4342 

## Testing Plan

- JS Unit Tests are included and updated to test DATE, DATETIME, and DATETIMETZ formats.
- Checking rendering of E2E Tests for the tooltip (like in the issue) is really difficult. Manual testing of this is possible with PR Preview.

---

**Contribution License Agreement**

By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.

body:
Running into the issue as well.

It seems like streamlit needs to set the scale property on the Tooltip as well as on the axis markers as per https://github.com/altair-viz/altair/issues/2077#issuecomment-1233424129

`alt.Tooltip(name, scale={'type': 'utc'})`

Though apparently Altair does not support this Vega feature, so this probably needs a fix in Altair first...
